original_data.question: A 45-year-old woman presents to the physician with a history of headache, palpitations, and episodic diaphoresis. She was diagnosed with hypertension in the past and is now regularly taking antihypertensive medication (amlodipine 10 mg once daily). She has had a diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 4 months. She complains of pain in the long bones of her arms and legs for the past 3 months. She is slightly built, appears thin, and is anxious and apprehensive. Her skin is moist and warm. Her weight is 45 kg (99.2 lb) and height is 146 cm (4 ft 7 in); BMI is 21.12 kg/m2. Her pulse is 116/min, the blood pressure is 196/102 mm Hg, the respiratory rate is 29/min, and the temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F). Diffuse and firm thyromegaly is present. Her upper extremities exhibit fine tremors during an anxiety attack. The laboratory test results reveal elevated 24-hour urinary VMA and metanephrines. Serum epinephrine, calcitonin, and parathormone levels are also elevated. Hypercalcemia and hyperglycemia are also noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

model_response: The patient's symptoms are suggestive of pheochromocytoma, which is a rare catecholamine-producing tumor that most commonly arises from the adrenal medulla. The clinical presentation is so variable that Pheochromocytoma has been termed "the great masquerader". The episodic hypertension is often accompanied by tachycardia, diaphoresis, anxiety, and headache. Classic signs of increased catecholamine levels such as paroxysmal sweating, tachycardia, and headaches are present in only 20% of patients. The diffuse thyroid swelling is due to the fact that pheochromocytoma can stimulate the thyroid gland to produce excessive amounts of thyroid hormone. The increased thyroid hormone production causes the symptoms of hyperthyroidism. The increased parathormone and calcitonin levels are due to the fact that pheochromocytoma can stimulate the parathyroid glands to produce excessive amounts of parathormone and calcitonin. The increased epinephrine and norepinephrine levels are due to the fact that pheochromocytoma can stimulate the adrenal medulla to produce excessive amounts of catecholamines. The increased serum glucose level is due to the fact that pheochromocytoma can stimulate the pancreas to produce excessive amounts of insulin. The increased serum calcium and blood sugar levels can lead to increased production of insulin. The increased serum calcium and parathormone levels can lead to increased bone resorption. The increased serum calcitonin level is due to the fact that pheochromocytoma can stimulate the thyroid gland to produce excessive amounts of calcitonin. The increased serum alkaline phosphatase level is due to the fact that pheochromocytoma can stimulate the bone-forming cells in the bone to increase their activity. The increased serum alkaline phosphatase level can lead to increased bone formation. The increased serum growth hormone level is due to the fact that pheochromocytoma can stimulate the anterior pituitary gland to produce excessive amounts of growth hormone. The increased serum growth hormone level can lead to increased bone resorption. The increased serum prolactin level is due to the fact that pheochromocytoma can stimulate the anterior pituitary gland to produce excessive amounts of prolactin. The increased serum prolactin level can lead to increased milk production. The increased serum renin level is due to the fact that pheochromocytoma can stimulate the kidney to produce excessive amounts of renin. The increased serum renin level can lead to increased production of angiotensin II. The increased serum T3 and T4 levels are due to the fact that pheochromocytoma can stimulate the thyroid gland to produce excessive amounts of T3 and T4. The increased serum T3 and T4 levels can lead to increased metabolic activity. The increased serum TSH level is due to the fact that pheochromocytoma can stimulate the anterior pituitary gland to produce excessive amounts of TSH. The increased serum TSH level can lead to increased thyroid hormone production. The increased serum VMA and metanephrines levels are due to the fact that pheochromocytoma can stimulate the adrenal medulla to produce excessive amounts of catecholamines. The increased serum VMA and metanephrines levels can lead to increased nervousness, sweating, and palpitations. The increased serum VMA and metanephrines levels can also lead to increased urinary output. The increased serum VMA and metanephrines levels can also lead to increased blood pressure. The increased serum VMA and metanephrines levels can also lead to increased heart rate. The increased serum VMA and metanephrines levels can also lead to increased respiratory rate. The increased serum VMA and metanephrines levels can also lead to increased body temperature. The increased serum VMA and metanephrines levels can also lead to increased appetite. The increased serum VMA and metanephrines levels can also lead to increased thirst.

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Record and study of past events.
The symptom of PAIN in the cranial region. It may be an isolated benign occurrence or manifestation of a wide variety of HEADACHE DISORDERS.
An unpleasant sensation of irregular and/or forceful beating of the heart.
Profuse sweating.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.

Persistently high systemic arterial BLOOD PRESSURE. Based on multiple readings (BLOOD PRESSURE DETERMINATION), hypertension is currently defined as when SYSTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently greater than 140 mm Hg or when DIASTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently 90 mm Hg or more.

Drugs used in the treatment of acute or chronic vascular HYPERTENSION regardless of pharmacological mechanism. Among the antihypertensive agents are DIURETICS; (especially DIURETICS, THIAZIDE); ADRENERGIC BETA-ANTAGONISTS; ADRENERGIC ALPHA-ANTAGONISTS; ANGIOTENSIN-CONVERTING ENZYME INHIBITORS; CALCIUM CHANNEL BLOCKERS; GANGLIONIC BLOCKERS; and VASODILATOR AGENTS.
A long-acting dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It is effective in the treatment of ANGINA PECTORIS and HYPERTENSION.
Occurring or done each day.

Enlargement of the THYROID GLAND that may increase from about 20 grams to hundreds of grams in human adults. Goiter is observed in individuals with normal thyroid function (euthyroidism), thyroid deficiency (HYPOTHYROIDISM), or hormone overproduction (HYPERTHYROIDISM). Goiter may be congenital or acquired, sporadic or endemic (GOITER, ENDEMIC).
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
A larger, elongated bone in the extremity.
The superior part of the upper extremity between the SHOULDER and the ELBOW.
The inferior part of the lower extremity between the KNEE and the ANKLE.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Feelings or emotions of dread, apprehension, and impending disaster but not disabling as with ANXIETY DISORDERS.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.
The vertical measurement or distance from the base to the top of an object; the vertical dimension of extension.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
Widely spread; not localized or confined.

Enlargement of the THYROID GLAND that may increase from about 20 grams to hundreds of grams in human adults. Goiter is observed in individuals with normal thyroid function (euthyroidism), thyroid deficiency (HYPOTHYROIDISM), or hormone overproduction (HYPERTHYROIDISM). Goiter may be congenital or acquired, sporadic or endemic (GOITER, ENDEMIC).
The region of the upper limb in animals, extending from the deltoid region to the HAND, and including the ARM; AXILLA; and SHOULDER.

Cyclical movement of a body part that can represent either a physiologic process or a manifestation of disease. Intention or action tremor, a common manifestation of CEREBELLAR DISEASES, is aggravated by movement. In contrast, resting tremor is maximal when there is no attempt at voluntary movement, and occurs as a relatively frequent manifestation of PARKINSON DISEASE.
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.
An elevated level or position or degree; greater than normal in degree or intensity or amount.
The duct which coveys URINE from the pelvis of the KIDNEY through the URETERS, BLADDER, and URETHRA.
A 3-O-methyl ether of 3,4-dihydroxymandelic acid. It is an end-stage metabolite of CATECHOLAMINES; EPINEPHRINE; and NOREPINEPHRINE.
Product of epinephrine O-methylation. It is a commonly occurring, pharmacologically and physiologically inactive metabolite of epinephrine.

The active sympathomimetic hormone from the ADRENAL MEDULLA. It stimulates both the alpha- and beta- adrenergic systems, causes systemic VASOCONSTRICTION and gastrointestinal relaxation, stimulates the HEART, and dilates BRONCHI and cerebral vessels. It is used in ASTHMA and CARDIAC FAILURE and to delay absorption of local ANESTHETICS.

A peptide hormone that lowers calcium concentration in the blood. In humans, it is released by thyroid cells and acts to decrease the formation and absorptive activity of osteoclasts. Its role in regulating plasma calcium is much greater in children and in certain diseases than in normal adults.
Parathyroid hormone (115 aa, ~13 kDa) is encoded by the human PTH gene. This protein is involved in the modulation of calcium ion and phosphate concentration in the blood.
An elevated level or position or degree; greater than normal in degree or intensity or amount.
Abnormally high level of calcium in the blood.
Abnormally high BLOOD GLUCOSE level.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
